but I would actually argue if you were starting from scratch and it turns out that about um actually also 75% of

you're starting from scratch that's 75% of you guys here um and you could you you want to

you something about the ratio between unit integration and UI tests anyway uh
just in case someone's not familiar with the concept so automated UI testing uh the the idea is to have a program a test
which simulates what the user does to an application and what does the user do well here she uh interacts with UI
controls right like tabing uh you know scrolling swiping entering text that's
what it user does to the application now you're going to simulate that uh in a
program so in order to do that uh you need to be able to talk about gestures
like tapping and swiping uh and you need to be able to talk about View use so um
uh the way we do that at least in our tool is that we have what we call a query language uh where you can specify
uh you know it's this exact button that I want to touch or it's this exact uh text I want to
find um and and there's kind of a nice little DSL declarative language there
and to let you easily do that so some examples here would be uh so this in C
in this case so application please tap uh anything that has uh the text the
string help uh whether it's a button or it's a text doesn't really matter just find something with the text help or
application please Tap The Element e which has the ID technical iD History
BTN history button our application please wait for Element e which has the text ink so this
is the kind of language you would use in a in a program like this to uh tell the program what to do to the application
like tapping waiting for event to occur like wait until there's no spinner visible on the
screen um in addition to these various gestures you can also generate
screenshots like I want to see what the application looks like just now uh save that to a file uh and you can manage the
app life cycle so launching uh stopping the application clearing the application data so you're starting from scratch
that's often something you need to do during a testing cycle like completely uninstall it install it again and start
from scratch and then some tools uh like ours allow us to uh actually do some things
that are pretty hard to do as a human um so one example would be to simulate the GPS location of the device so I'm
writing a test that says given I'm uh in you know Oslo Airport um and I I tap the
book button or whatever uh and then the next step you say now um set the
location to London so you're pretending that you're flying from muso to London and you you can do that now within um
you know milliseconds um and another thing you can do is actually like very low level
is basically grab an object inside the application and start calling methods on it it's a pretty Advanced thing not
necessarily something you need to do but it can be uh extremely handy um to say
to speed up the test or set the application into a specific State all right so that's a basic
overview automated UI testing so simulate a user using the application
now uh there are a ton of different uh tools and Frameworks out there that you
can use to uh to run these and write these UI tests so the example you saw
before uh is from Samar UI test which is one of our own products uh which is

and iOS applications and basically you can run them uh you can write these things inside nunit tests and run them from
inside sammon Studio or Visual Studio or from the command line if you want there's also support for a spec
flow if you're familiar with that uh there's a system called Calabash which is very similar except that you are
writing your test now Ruby and you're running them using uh a tool called cucumber which is like a behavior driven
development tool so that's kind of matching what you do in your company then maybe you want to go down that
route then there's a different slightly newer um option out there which which is called appium and the idea with appium
is you know what we this UI testing stuff we already did it like it's selenium right it's selenium web driver
if you're familiar with that um so basically IDE there the idea there is
that uh a lot of companies have people who've been writing selenium web browser scripts and why don't we see if we can

python JavaScript whatever language you want um that you can kind of use already
it's already out there um the the downside I think is
that you're getting a bit of an impedance mismatch because a browser is not the same as mobile native

with the platform sdks uh and they use the language of the platforms which in this case is Java and
Objective C or Swift U but they're not crossplatform so if you write a test for Android it's not

applications aren't actually built like this so there I recommend that you uh use
something called the page object pattern which is a actually a very simple idea it is to ex abstract um uh the logic of
the test into uh classes that we call Page objects uh for instance you may have a uh an object that represents the
login page let's see if we can find that so here login page on the login
page I might log in via Facebook I might skip authentication and those become methods and then you push the
application uh the iOS versus Android specific logic into those me methods
which enables you to reuse the high level logic of the test script so that's how you structure your test if you want
C crossplatform testing uh for instance here on the login page I can skip off um in this
case it's actually crossplatform because you can just do uh app. tap the tech skip off which is the same on IOS and
Android but if you see if we wanted to log in via Facebook we actually have this kind
of interesting construct here which is on Android the selector the ID for the uh
log in via Facebook button is button Facebook but on iOS it's login with
Facebook so this means we actually have a bit of branching but at least that branching is pushed into uh this
abstraction that we call the login page um so if you're going to build
these uh applications trying to be mindful of the tester so put in the same IDs so you minimize the branching and if

software discipline where you build your application in such a way that it can can be deployed to production at any
time so your quality is high enough and your procedures for deployment are high
enough or good enough that at any given time if there's a business requirement to get an update out there you can just
do it now this is not the same to say as that you're always
automatically uh pushing out updates without human interaction that's usually called continuous deployment it means
that's happening automatically it's a system it's pushing out production system all the time the difference between continuous
deployment and which is that and continuous delivery is uh with delivery you could do it if you wanted to but
it's still a human that goes in and pushes the button to deliver the application to app store or to deploy the

apps and if you do this you're going to get the same types of benefits as you do with other
systems uh so what are those benefits um basically the three major ones are
you're going to reduce your lead time uh and so what is that so the lead time is the time from someone fixes a bug or
until from the time someone gets an idea until the implementation of that bug fix
or that idea is in the hands of the users that's going to be reduced because you're continuously delivering you're
continuously uh pushing your application out or deploying your software to production so that bug fix doesn't have
to wait to get batched up with a production deployment that happens three months from now so you're faster to get
things out this also means in turn you're getting faster feedback right because if you get the thing out there
faster well then the user has a chance to respond earlier right uh but there's also from a technical perspective
there's faster feedback because continuous uh deliveries associated with a lot of automation like automated
builds automated tests so for instance if a developer makes a change that breaks the build well then immediately

bux and which is wayless costly and finally the uh uh release itself is of
higher quality because just just less stuff in there right it's a smaller batch because you're continuously
